title: Readable handwriting font
content:
Hi, I'm designing a cook book and it needs to have a "home made" feel so using a handwritten font for tips and explanations ... I have used Quickpen ( [https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/trial-by-cupcakes/quickpen/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232610/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/trial-by-cupcakes/quickpen/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/trial-by-cupcakes/quickpen/")) which I love but the client has decided they want something that they think is more readable. Just wondering if anyone has any suggestions? I like the shape and flow of quickpen - would love something with a similar feel and welcome any feedback from here.  
Thanks!
author: Meloncally

comments.content:
I like Rollerscript ( [http://www.g-type.com/rollerscript-font](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232610/http:/www.g-type.com/rollerscript-font "http://www.g-type.com/rollerscript-font")), but am not sure it could be considered much more readable.  
Maybe something from Blue Vinyl ( [http://www.myfonts.com/foundry/Blue\_Vinyl\_Fonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232610/http:/www.myfonts.com/foundry/Blue_Vinyl_Fonts/ "http://www.myfonts.com/foundry/Blue\_Vinyl\_Fonts/"))

Many thanks... Rollerscript is a lovely font and exactly what I'm after for the look of the book. I agree it might not be as readable as the client wants but I'll give it a go! Will also check out the Blue Vinyl fonts.  
Thanks again.
Thanks for buying Rollerscript Cally. I'd say it's just as readable as Quickpen, just different. I'd like to see it in use if the client goes for it.
...And thanks for linking to my site Riccardo.
